The only negative I'd have to say is that the last few levels were really difficult for me and I made my boyfriend do most of the bits because I couldn't, I probably would of if I practiced over and over. reviewText:
ibb&obb is a really fun and addicting game if you play it together with a good friend of yours. I highly recommend buying the 2-pack bundle and to play with a friend.

The game is kind of a physics puzzle platformer. It is self-explanatory, from the first to the last stage you will see new elements being introduced in a way that requires no further explanation. It's intuitive and fun to explore the new elements.

The music in this game is a highlight. It matches the clean, calming artstyle perfectly and fits the athmosphere of the stages perfectly. Get the soundtrack if you can, you won't regret it.

The replay-value of this game is ok. As long as you have more friends to play it with, there will always be one who you can introduce to this game and trying to get 100% of the crystals and secret stages with them is just as fun as trying it for the first time.

What I dislike is that the audio volume resets every time you start the game, it's far too loud. Also, when playing with friends from overseas, the game suffers heavily from lag - not really the games fault, but I found that to be annoying sometimes, anyway.

I'd recommend this game to anyone who hasn't played it yet and who has a friend to play this together with. I could imagine that single player is too hard, as you'd have to control both characters at once, but maybe you'll like the challenge of that, too.

reviewText:
I wish I could recommend this game, but there are issues which cannot be ignored. I can't in good conscience say that someone should get this game until they're fixed. I will admit though that some of these issues are due to being disabled, which will result in some hate (because as we know the only people who like disabled people are disabled people), but I need to talk about this.

Screen Zooming

I have poor sight, so when the screen suddenly zooms way out I find it easy to lose track of my character, or I'll get vertigo and my precision will be off. In a game with online multiplayer, this kind of zooming is unnecessary and only serves to irritate the player. An online game should use a set zoom (with the zoom level in the options). A pointer could point the position of the other character. This wouldn't really require much extra code as there's a pointer that tracks the other player in-game right now (if one player goes too high off screen, it'll show the position of the player lower down), which makes this even more baffling.

If this were fixed for online games, it would make the experience much more enjoyable. As it is, the constant stretching and shrinking, stretching and shrinking, stretching and shrinking makes me feel nauseous. I understand that a temporary zoom to show what you need to do may sometimes be necessary, but just trigger that then have the zoom go away. Or even give the player a 'zoom out' toggle key which they can use whenever they want.

But making it zoom and zip around like mad makes it feel like a Ubisoft game where the controls are so often stolen away. This would be a much, much, much more playable experience if this was fixed.

Collectibles

I have an anxiety disorder. Whenever I fail to get collectibles, I feel like I've failed my co-op partner. For some people, this is exciting, exhilarating, and fun. For me, it results in my heart racing, pounding, and feeling faint and panicky. That sense of panic will grow and my hands will start shaking. Combine this with the above issue and I find ibb & obb (especially on the harder levels) a genuinely unpleasant play experience.

This could be fixed by having an option so that they don't decay. I know that there are some nutty, obsessive cheevo-hunters out there who're hardcore or no-core, so just disabled the Steam achievements tied in with collectibles if the co-op partners agree to turn on the option to stop the collectibles from decaying. That way, it's an option, which doesn't hurt anyone, and the hardcore cheevo-hunters can have their hadcore cheevo-hunting.

As it is, though, the decay makes this a stressful experience. Otherwise, it would be a pleasant, enjoyable, serene, cerebral experience. It would be more like Portal 2, then. I love Portal 2, standing around and trying to figure out a test chamber without the immediate pressure of ermahgerd I stepped on a thing, now the collectibles are going to decay, whatever will I do? So I won't be playing much more ibb & obb due to this.

Of course, this means that the collectibles will stick around if you die, too. I know, gosh, such a carebear. But I'm an old fart with disabilities, I'm not 15 any more. We can't all be perfect.

It just really, really frustrates me because I could see the potential of this as a serene puzzler, it could be in my top ten with the likes of Myst and Portal, but this silly, ridiculous design decision to cause stress and anxiety for no good reason just does so, so much to ruin the game. And it does ruin the game. And it is stupid. And it does stop it from reaching its potential. I just want to shake some sense into the developers, because it could be so much more. It's so close to being an epic cult classic for the ages.

Are you looking for another fun puzzle game? As a fan of the genre myself, I can say I look often. This game stood out for it's art style, co-op, and simplicity.

When it comes to puzzle platformers, ibb & obb uses a recently popular mind-bending alteration on physics. Many of its peer platformers have also used dual or mirrored characters, but not quite in this same way. In those, you the player are able to control both. Here, each character must fend for himself, but also cooperate to succeed. It has taken cues from the co-op element of Portal, but is still self-contained.

While I typically don't enjoy platformers in the genre, this was an exception. Simplicity is key, and the developers executed it very well. It doesn't remain the same throughout, and there is clear progression in the art, but it's always minimal, clean, and fresh. The smooth dream-like artistry behind it, including the music, is excellent and I applaud it.

There is hardly any story, which is fine with this game, and what exists is only shown visually, and you are up to interpret it. It's not as integral, but makes for a neat dynamic if you think about it. I think this part could be developed further. While it's clean, and I like that, it's not overly progressed. It appears, and then goes nowhere. Because of this, it doesn't stick with you long after you play. It's good and lovely mental and cooperative exercise, but not much more.

The puzzle difficulty is variable, and you can choose to pursue more challenging ones that don't hinder you from the main drive. Co-op makes this a lot of fun, as you decipher these physics traps together. It's a good communication and team-building exercise also. It certainly delivers on mental puzzlers, and if you enjoy them, I recommend it to you.

I have been having an absolute blast playing this game with my friend. It's a similar experience to what we had playing Portal 2 co-op, occasionally hurting our brains trying to solve a puzzle and then facepalming when it becomes blatantly obvious (after you've spent 15 mins trying to solve it of course). ibb & obb actually has us both in tears a few times, just dying with laughter as we repeatedly fail jumps and die to the Studio Ghibli-esque wandering soots.

The graphics are PHENOMENAL - the simplicity of it all works so well and the vibrant colours make me so happy. Even the darker levels were executed so well and add to the game: You have just enough vision so that it doesn't hinder you playing (like so many other games where you can't see 2 inches in front of your face) and it's fun not being able to see the soots. Nothing like a spikey lil surprise to make your day eh?

Not gonna lie, I normally rage a bit while playing platformer/repeatedly dying games. Like I said earlier I've had the exact opposite happen..I cry with laughter when we keep dying. reviewText:
This game is cute, has great music and challenging puzzles. And you play it in cooperation with a buddy. What's not to like?

The puzzles are challenging not only in regard to their solution. They often require both players to perfectly execute several steps in a row, with very little room for error. This can mean that you have already figured out the solution and make it halfway there but then you misstep: Start over. Then, your friend is too fast: Start over. Then, you jump a little too early:  Start over. Then, your friend hits an enemy: You know the drill. Solving a puzzle can get quite tedious.
Another issue is savegames: One level took us up to an hour (in the later stages), depending both of how well we could crack the puzzle logic and execute the steps. During that, the game saved our progress just fine; if we failed a puzzle, we'd only be back at its beginning. But whenever we had to quit before finishing the level (or had a desync or just didn't feel like trying the same puzzle for the umpteenth time), the next time, we'd have to restart the whole level from the beginning.
Finally, playing it with a friend across the ocean, we found that in-game voice chat was delayed by a few seconds. Maybe it doesn't happen with less of a distance between you and your co-player. For us, it didn't help, what with some puzzles needing near-perfect timing. Towards the end, we thought about using an external solution like Raidcall, but it never came to that.
Overall, the game can get quite frustrating.

Before this, we played Portal 2, which did a better job of e.g. the savegame issue by having many smaller levels, so if you had to quit at some point, you wouldn't have to replay as much as in this game. And there, when you already knew the steps leading up to where you'd left off, they were usually pretty easy to reproduce. If you're looking for a fun coop puzzler, I'd rather recommend Portal 2.

reviewText:
Ibb & Obb is a gravity-based puzzle-platformer.

Which isn't to say you manually adjust gravity, as with some games, but that the entire game is composed of things like 'slow fall bubbles', trampolines, looped falling (where you drop from the sky after falling off the bottom of the screen), and reverse-gravity wells.

Despite fairly simple concepts, the puzzles quickly move from charming and cute and simple, to demanding and clever.

Unlike twitch/reflex platformers, once you actually figure out the trick to a puzzle, you're good to move on, which makes this a game more about testing your wit, than your reflexes- though timing is certainly important, as well.

Ibb & Obb is one of the best co-op experiences I've had in a while, and I can certainly recommend it-
Though there's some things I unfortunately have to point out.

||PROS||
* Co-op only play guarantees an experience built with co-op in mind at all facets.

* Puzzles are based around clever reuses of a small set of objects, presented in more and more complex ways, thus creating a steadily progressing experience where you build off what you've learned from your previous successes, rather than having to start each puzzle from scratch.

* Ibb & Obb (the two player-controlled characters in the game) are different sizes. This can have some interesting effects on gameplay, and is actually crucial to later puzzles. It's a nice twist that keeps each co-op partner feeling distinct in their roles. Similarly, the use of color-coded barriers limits which character can progress at points, creating interesting 'how do we both progress' puzzles.

* Looped falling can be surprisingly hilarious

* You can 'bend the system' by attempting crazy mid-air combos, such as trying to jump off your partner as they loop-fall. This can sometimes provide alternative ways to solve puzzles, for players that enjoy precision-reflex approaches over puzzle approaches. But really, it'll take quite a few attempts to do- though it's quite satisfying when you manage it.

* Charming atmosphere, and the most adorable little interactables- that you can actually push into enemies to cause the enemies to change course, or bounce onto enemy killing buttons, or just kick around like soccer balls, sometimes to absolutely hilarious effect. Great little tidbit for more creative puzzle solving, and just general palate cleansing.

* The ability to aim for a perfect score, by gathering all the enemy-kill score drops, for the more dedicated completionists.

||NEUTRAL||
* Secret stages are brutal and difficult to intuit, and may be best skipped by all but the most dedicated mental gymnasts.

* This game gets hard. It looks like it's designed for kids, but most kids won't have the patience to complete this kid of game [and if you know one that does, give them a cookie, they're awesome].  This is definitely a game for the patient and the people who really like working through problems until they understand them.
If you're into really puzzle-oriented games, enjoy teamwork, and physics manipulation, you're going to probably like this game. If your expectations run toward something more- or less- active in involvement, you may not.


* Similarly, puzzles will require several attempts to figure out, and at the time we played, all the walkthroughs were for the console version (which has different stages, see Cons below). Plus side, every time we got stuck and needed an assist, it was us overthinking a puzzle, so there's that. :)
Still, patience is a virtue- and one you may need to rely on for this game.
Then again, you'll still die less, hate yourself less, and feel far less frustrated than with twitch/reflex platformers, so there's that~

* Relatively short. 6 to 7 hours without the last level (see Cons), but that's mostly due to repetition in figuring out each puzzle. The core content is probably 2-3 hours in length, assuming a run-through where you know what you're doing.
(Secret levels will of course extend this time a bit further, if you choose to do them.)

||CONS||

* The last level is broken on the PC port- or rather, several levels got reimagined for the PC port (which is kinda cool) but the reimagining of the last level caused it to be incompletable (which is kinda not cool).
The game plays fine up to that point, so if you're able to view the end of the game being a level sooner, you'll be fine-
If you're a completionist, this screw-up may drive you up a wall.
Especially with given how demanding the prior level was- you can only imagine how awesome this final level could have been..

* No mid-level save points, so you're forced to complete a stage to make progression in it.
[Each puzzle section within a stage does have its own respawn point, however.]
Plus side, once you know the puzzles, you can breeze through if you need to leave and restart- still, this feels like an unfortunate and arbitrary exclusion.

* Likewise, this game seems to have low replay value, given that non-campaign-level challenges (ie, secret levels) are all extreme in challenge, and all puzzles in the game are fairly easy to complete once you know how to do them.


This is a bit of a difficult game to describe, but if you like undertaking a mental challenge with a partner, and neither of you are the type to get agitated when you get stuck, then it's a fantastic game I recommend highly.

As always with co-operation games of this nature, if either person gets easily stressed, expect eventual argument and rage-quitting.
Despite that phrasing, it's not an especially frustrating game (in MY opinion), since everything CAN be figured out through rethinking and continously retesting your approach to a puzzle.


Still, it's a bit niche in its challenge, a bit curious in how certain things (like secret levels) are approached, and, of course, the last level cannot be played.

So..
I tentatively give it a 4/5.

Seriously, if it sounds at all good to you, give it a shot- and if it sounds at all not good to you, don't. ~.^

reviewText:
ibb & obb might be the most adorable game I've ever seen.

Psychedelic colors swirl around the screen, weird geometric characters dance about, parties are thrown for no reason whatsoever; it's just so 'effing cute and I wanted so much to fall in love with it. But playing ibb & obb is like petting a dog and having it bite your fingers off. It's cuteness is equally matched if not exceeded by its degree of frustrating, nonsensical design decisions, to where my head began to hurt so much I'm not sure how I ever managed to complete the trek through hell that was somehow hiding below the delightful exterior.

Just to be entirely clear, ibb & obb is coop only, meaning you better have a friend ready and willing to brave its horrors with you before you even press start. And to this point there are some pretty cool ideas buried here, which force you to play cooperatively and make clever use of its main gravity inverting hook. There are two sides to every level, with each flipping your character over like you've cut a hole straight through to the other side of the world and gravity hasn't yet realized.

Using both characters in tandem is almost always required to allow both to progress, be it providing a step up onto a ledge or using momentum to carry each other through. It's a fantastic hook but its implementation here is unbelievably hamstrung and convoluted. The camera that has to contend with two characters often going in opposite directions bears much of the blame, often obscuring parts of the environment or even your character entirely as you fight against it to keep moving as it holds you back. The pretty environments come at the const of making levels difficult to even comprehend, often blending so well with platforms or bubbles I needed to float in that I often had no idea they were something I needed to interact with.

Puzzle designs, while on occasion genuinely brilliant, are often constructed such a ridiculous manner that numerous times throughout the game I thought we were breaking the game finding their solutions. So many moments are needlessly tedious and absurdly challenging, forcing literal split-second timing which its floaty, imprecise controls make cumbersome at the best of times and a living nightmare at its worst. Each new mechanic introduced only seems to worsen the already overburdened experience, leaving exasperated and fatigued before I was even halfway through. The abundance of network lag (which from what I've gathered is by no means an isolated issue) made parts of the game nearly impassible, as if the game was at last telling me to give up as my character ran wildly around at his own inclination.

The dissonance between ibb & obb's truly marvelous artwork and mellow soundtrack and it's reprehensible gameplay is probably one of the most shocking I've ever experienced. It's bewildering and depressing, and I'm still finding it hard to fathom how miserable an experience it was to play when it all seemed so wonderful from the outside.

reviewText:
I wrote a lengthy version on gamespot.com, with fancy images. ( http://www.gamespot.com/ibb-and-obb/user-reviews/2200-12659853/ )

But to summarize,

NEGATIVE POINTS

- The controls are a bit cheap, lack the ability to move precisely, which is needed in many situations in the game.
Little reason to actually collect the points, more frustration than reward.

- Unclear whether the player is in the middle or near the end of the level.

- One of the important mechanics blends in too well with the background, making it unclear.

NEUTRAL POINTS

- Level designing is fairly good but could be much better in some areas.

POSITIVE POINTS

- Mechanics and concept are neat.

- Creating a 2player platform puzzler is not an easy job.

- Aesthetics are fitting and look good.

- Particle effect on the cursor aids gameplay really well.


I'd say 12 bucks is too much for the frustration though, if they simply made it a shorter game (with the quality > quantity mindset), spent some more time on the movement, leveldesign and some clearer indications I think this game would be awesome, but for this, no. I wouldn't recommend it.

reviewText:
ibb & obb is an incredibly artful, simplistic game. You play as some sort of mushroom-blob, guiding your respective mushroom-blob friend to the exit of the levels. It sounds like a simple puzzle game formula that has been tried before.

However, this puzzle game manages to set itself apart. In the very short time I have played it, I have found the game incredibly fluid and polished, the art and animation smooth and fitting to the core gameplay, and the gameplay itself fantastic. It's the kind of game you can pick up and play with a friend so easily, and then can't put down.

The puzzles start out seemingly easy, but continue to get trickier and trickier. The lack of communication besides what you can waggle out with your mouse only adds to the fun, and you'll probaby find yourself either laughing hysterically or screaming frustratedly as one of you grasps the puzzle while the other does not. I can imagine having an unskilled/trolling teammate would somewhat diminish this experience, but if you're in the right mindset, with the right teammate, you'll have a blast.

TL;DR: 9/10. One of my favorite puzzle games I've ever played. Hope to see more.

reviewText:
Tried hard to be modern and artsy, but the 'PhyreEngine' unfortunately does not provide magical tricks to remove online delay, hence this 2p-coop-only timing puzzle videogame falls flat as an online experience. From what other reviewers wrote, it doesn't even work properly via LAN.
If it were couch coop only, I'd moan that there's no online MP, but as it stands, I have to moan that the online MP isn't very good. Later levels are just about impossible due to the atrocious lag / delay and random erratic AI behaviour resulting from this.

I sure like the comparably cheap two pack offer, but the bugginess / glitchiness as well as frequent reliance more on perfect timing than clever thinking prevents me from giving this game a positive review. Unlike it apparently was the case for other reviewers, my 1.5 hours of playing time did not include 'lightbulb moments' where I was mesmerised by the developers' astonishingly intricate puzzle design. At all. As far as challenging players with pattern memorisation and perfect timing goes, there are various games on Steam that make far far better use of those gameplay elements (SMB, Rush Bros and I assume Electronic Super Joy as well as SpeedRunners).

Give this game a look if you engage in regular single PC dual gamepad multiplayer games, or if you happen to have a lot of patience for a game's issues when it comes to playing online with a close friend.

P.S.: Voice communication is a must for all but the first few puzzlies. Not gonna be any jolly if you can't communicate while you play.

Ibb & Obb is a delightful indie co-op platforming experience but you need a buddy to play along with. It's strictly a co-op game, so that means either playing with a good friend or with random players. Like classic platforming, you run to the right and overcome obstacles together, the twist being that you have the ability to walk underneath the floor, parallel to the top. Many of the puzzles and enemies must be solved by using this ability, with one player being on top of the world and one underneath. There have been times where we have been stumped at how to progress thanks to this clever little mechanic. Momentum and jumping physics also play parts in the challenges for you to utilize. The game isn't the longest in the world, 3 hours and more for the secrets and collectibles scattered and hidden throughout. Visually, it's simple, using highly vectored and clean graphics with simple enemy design. You will see alot of back drops and paths being re-used with the difference being colours and ambience. The difficulty is pretty tame until the late stages which then ramps up like a bridge. Not a bad thing but you'll find yourself suddenly hitting a wall and being stuck.

Although I have only played with a friend, i can see this being a difficult time with random players. You might have trouble with players who lack patience or rush ahead leaving you behind. There is no in game chat that I know of, with the only intstructions you can give is by moving the mouse around to draw lines and paths if you're trying to show how to progress.

Overall, 3/5.

Synchronization through vocal communication is important. The game provides no way to synchronize actions other than skill alone. It does not feature hand holding countdown timers through a button press nor gameplay elements favoring synchronization.

The directional controls feel like there is something uncanny about the acceleration rate, inertia and friction.

The above combined makes it so that several puzzle elements are frustrating because they are non deterministic. A slight variation in position or momentum will cause your character to move in various ways with a difficult to predict outcome, meaning that a puzzle section has to be attempted many many many times before any success, even if you already know how the puzzle is meant to be solved.

Some puzzles will require one specific player to execute one specific part of a puzzle. There are sometimes an urge to swap roles which can't be done.


It may be difficult to have two players stay engaged through the entire game. The overall longevity of the game is obfuscated because an entire chapter may have such frustrating puzzles we had to stop at the end of each chapter and resume days later.

So, I forget where I first read about this game. Probably somewhere in the vijagame jouranlisms.  I really liked the visual aesthetic and the idea of a puzzle platformer built not just with co-op in mind, but built entirely around co-op as a necessary central mechanic.  I ended up playing the first level and a half solo just to get a feel for the game, and came away with the impression that it was going to be a cute, clever, but ultimately soft experience.

That was quite some time ago.  Recently got into it seriously with a friend, and damn, my initial impression was proven wrong.  This game is certainly cute but it is anything but soft.  ibb & obb will challenge your brain meat.  The semi-hidden bonus stages especially; they gave us several excellent opporutnities to flex our brain muscle and were always very satisfying to solve.  Considering all your character can do is move and jump, it's amazing the depth of puzzles they're able to create with concepts like maintaining or building momentum or manipulating which direction gravity pulls your character.

The only basic mechanic you have other than moving and jumping is a little colorful bubble trail thing you can create with either the mouse or the right stick, if you're using a controller.  It's the only communication tool you have in-game, and I was impressed with how much information we were able to convey to each other using this simple, visual medium.  Of course sometimes we had to open a chat window to talk deeper strategy, but still it's an elegant solution for the issue of communication between players that fits in with the game's minimalist approach to it's mechanics and aesthetic.

I only have a couple negative points to share. The game starts out slow as you learn the mechanics and builds up the complexity on a pretty satisfying curve, but there are a couple challenges that boil down to basically challenges to your manual dexterity rather than your abilty to problem solve, and those are never as satsifying.  Secondly, we played online and towards the end experienced some pretty bad lag, which the game was not always good at mitigating.  We ended up with some weird lag artifacts like random enemies spawning in locations they shouldn't that only damaged one of the two players, or multiple copies of either ibb or obb respawning at once, or just really long wait times to respawn after death. Generally play was smooth and honestly you have to expect some problems when you play online over a crappy connection, but when the lag got particularly bad, the game had more trouble with it than I was expecting.

It's a relatively short game but there's so few games out there that are anything like it, and those few hours are densely packed.  ibb & obb is pure gameplay; there's no text or any exposition of any kind anywhere in the game.  If you dig platformers and puzzlers and various combinations thereof, and you've got a friend with similar interests, there are certainly less engaging ways you could split $14.  love that the Best Friends Forevr" double-pack only costs two dollars more than one copy on its own. While this game does many things very well, there are a couple that really bothered me.


Pros

The game has a very cute and minimalist aesthetic that I enjoyed.
The puzzles have a pretty good difficulty curve, with progressively more challenging puzzles.
I also liked how the game exhibited new mechanics. There are virtually no words throughout the game, and the game does a nice job of showing you how to do something before you do it (at least for the beginning puzzles).


Neutral

The controls felt a bit off at first. The jump felt a little too floaty. But after about 10 minutes, it wasn't hard to adjust to it.


Cons
While I said that the difficulty curve is fine overall, much of the latter part relies too heavily on being able to precisely time and coordinate movements between your partner with little room for error. If you or your partner mess up, you'll have to retry.
My main gripe however, which will probably sound pretty inconsequential, is the fact that the game doesn't exactly excel. The game does things well, but not really well enough to stand out. It makes nice use of it's gravity-changing doorways, so they don't feel tacked on, but unfortunately, there's not much else to set it apart, and with so many indie puzzle platformers, you really need to do so.

It can be hard to find someone who is as good as you are at a game and ALSO wants to play it with you at the same time that you do. As this game depends on cooperation (most of this game's puzzles require a high-degree of cooperation) you need to play this with someone who is as competent at the game as you are and despite how cute this game looks, there are some fairly mind-bending puzzles in this game, but that's also a good part of this game's charm.

The music in this game is excellent. The sound is good and cute. The graphics are cute. The game runs really, really well. The controls are, if you are a platform gamer, intuitive. But you MUST find someone else who thinks the controls are intuitive as well. Your mother who only plays complex scrabble-type word games and who has never managed to win a super mario brothers game won't be good enough at this and so the game will be sort of frustrating. This really is one of those games, like the cooperative mode of portal 2, where you should ideally be playing with someone you know really well and who is at least as good at the game as you are.
